page.title: 13Kidderminster, Brinton's
page.content: Until 1887 the town possessed no large public open space. In that year, however, John Brinton, who became the town's greatest benefactor of his generation, acquired the freehold of a 24 acre site known as Sutton Common, which faced the Stourport and Sutton Roads. He offered to present this to the town, an offer which was gratefully accepted, and on 1st August,1887, the site was formally opened as "The Brinton Park". In 1905 an additional 6 acres in Sutton Road became available; this land was purchased by the Council for an addition to Brinton Park, and was opened on 12th May, 1906. In its early years the Park was not used to its full capacity, perhaps because the people found it strange to have a park of their own.
